Technical Assistance Report 
Project Number: 49173  
Project Preparatory Technical Assistance (PPTA) 
October 2015 
 
 
 
Mongolia: Preparing the Improving Access to Health 
Services for Disadvantaged Groups Project 
(Financed by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction) 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
This  document  is  being  disclosed  to  the  public  in  accordance  with  ADB's  Public 
Communications Policy 2011.  
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

PROJECT PREPARATORY TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
1.  The project preparatory technical assistance (TA) is needed to (i) reach a consensus 
among stakeholders on a project that will expand health services primarily in ger (traditional 
tent) areas of Ulaanbaatar, and (ii) bring in international best practices to improve project design.  
 
B.  Major Outputs and Activities 
2.  The TA will develop an appropriate project design and all Asian Development Bank 
(ADB) required documents for Board consideration. The expected TA outputs are (i) urban 
primary health care strengthened, (ii) district hospital services improved, (iii) single purchaser of 
health services established, and (iv) project development and management. There will be two 
participatory and consultative stakeholder workshops, and small-scale surveys and focus group 
discussions organized under the TA with the Ministry of Health and Sports (MOHS).

C.  Cost Estimate and Proposed Financing Arrangement  
4.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,100,000 equivalent, of which $1,000,000 equivalent will 
be financed on a grant basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction, and administered by 
ADB. The government has agreed to provide $100,000 counterpart support in the form of office 
accommodation, venues for workshops and training, communication facilities for consultants, 
remuneration  and  per  diem  of  counterpart  staff,  administrative  support,  and  other  in-kind 
contributions. The detailed cost estimate is presented in Table A3.2.

D.  Consulting Services 
5.  ADB  will  engage  a  consulting  firm  to  provide  a  team  of  national  consultants                 
(32  person-months)  and  international  consultants  (26  person-months),  and  a  national 
environmental firm. The consulting firm will be recruited in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on 
the Use of Consultants (2013, as amended from time to time) using a simplified technical 
proposal and quality- and cost-based selection with a ratio of 90:10. The national environmental 
firm will be recruited through consultants’ qualifications selection. The outline terms of reference 
for the project preparatory TA consultants are described in paras. 8 to 19.

6.  Senior health systems specialist and team leader (international, 4.0 person-months). 
The international consultant will have a postgraduate degree in medicine, public health, or a 
related field. S/he will demonstrate 15 years of experience in health systems, hospital and 
project development, and team leadership. S/he will lead the team of consultants, submit all

3 
 
required TA outputs of the team of consultants, and design and document an appropriate 
project in line with ADB requirements. 
 
7.  Health  services  delivery  specialist  (international,  3.0  person-months).  The 
international consultant will have a postgraduate degree in medicine, public health, or a related 
field. S/he will demonstrate 10 years of experience in health systems and primary health care 
(PHC) development. S/he will prepare a situation and gap analysis of urban PHC and design 
the project for output 1, including innovative model family health centers. 
 
8.  Public-private partnership expert in health (international, 2.0 person-months). The 
international consultant will have a postgraduate degree in economics or business management, 
or a related field. S/he will demonstrate 10 years of experience in public-private partnership 
(PPP) in social sectors, preferably in the health sector. S/he will provide intensive training on 
private  sector  engagement  and  PPP  for  MOHS  and  Ulaanbaatar  City  Health  Department, 
prepare a capacity development plan in private health sector management and PPP for MOHS 
and Ulaanbaatar City Health Department, and identify and design PPP approaches in the 
primary care and hospital sector. 
 
9.  Health sector planning specialist (international, 3.0 person-months). The international 
consultant  will  have  a  postgraduate  degree  in  public  health  or  a  related  field.  S/he  will 
demonstrate 10 years of experience in health planning and systems development, including 
strong information and technology expertise in the area of health planning. S/he will assess 
current health planning methods, design a technology-based planning tool, and provide training. 
 
10.  Senior health insurance expert (international, 3.0 person-months). The international 
consultant will have a postgraduate degree in health economics, financing, or a related field. 
S/he  will  demonstrate  10  years  of  experience  in  health  financing  and  health  insurance 
development, and an excellent understanding of public finance systems. S/he will identify the 
legal and regulatory changes, prepare a capacity development plan, and develop a plan for 
pooling of state and health insurance funding. 
 
11.  Poverty,  social,  and  gender  specialist  (international,  1.5  person-months).  The 
international specialist will have a postgraduate degree in social sciences or related fields with  
8 years of relevant experience. S/he will carry out a poverty and social analysis (PSA) in 
accordance  with  ADB  requirements,  including  a  gender  analysis  to  identify  project-related 
gender gaps and disparities.1 A summary poverty reduction and social strategy, and a social 
and gender action plan will be prepared. 
 
12.  Financial  and  economic  specialist  (international,  2.0  person-months).  The 
international specialist will have a graduate degree in business, finance, or economics and will 
have 10 years of experience in project financial and economic analysis. S/he will conduct a 
financial and economic analysis of the project, prepare detailed cost tables; and undertake 
financial management capacity assessment of MOHS and the implementing agency for output 3. 
 
13.  Procurement  specialist (international, 2.0  person-months). The  specialist  will  have      
8 years of experience in international procurement. S/he will prepare the project procurement 
plan,  undertake  a  procurement  capacity  assessment,  prepare  draft  procurement  bidding 
documents, and prepare consultant recruitment documentation. 
 
                                                
1  ADB. 2012. Handbook on Poverty and Social Analysis: A Working Document. Manila.

4 
 
14.  Environment specialist (international, 1.5 person-months). The international specialist 
will  have  10  years  of  experience  in  conducting  project  environmental  impact  assessment. 
Experience in Mongolia is a plus. S/he will coordinate preparation of domestic environmental 
safeguard  requirements,  and  prepare  an  initial  environmental  examination,  including 
environmental safeguard due diligence and an environmental management plan in English that 
follows ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009) and the International Finance Corporation’s 
(World Bank Group) Environmental, Health, and Safety (EHS) Guidelines (2007); and responds 
to Mongolia safeguards requirements.2 
 
15.  Health  facility  planner  (international,  4.0  person-months).  The  expert  will  be  an 
experienced health facility planner with at least 10 years of experience in the establishment of 
modern PHC facilities and hospitals. S/he will conceptualize and design model family health 
centers and district hospitals while ensuring compliance with universal design, and develop 
downstream terms of reference. 
 
16.  The national experts will (i) work in tandem with the international specialists to assist in 
all tasks under the international experts’ terms of reference, and (ii) act as interpreters and 
translate  documents  as  required.  The  national  consultants  will  have  at  least  8  years  of 
experience in their respective area of assignment. 
 
17.  National accredited environmental firm (lumpsum). The firm will be an environmental 
accredited and reputable local firm recruited hired through a consultants’ qualifications selection 
to prepare a request for a general environmental impact assessment and prepare a detailed 
environmental impact assessment as required. 
 
E.  Implementation Arrangements 
18.  The TA will be implemented over 14 months from 1 November 2015 to 31 December 
2016. MOHS will be the executing agency for the TA. No project management unit will be 
established. The proceeds of the TA will be disbursed in accordance with ADB’s Technical 
Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). The TA equipment 
will be procured in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2015, as amended from 
time to time) and transferred to the executing agency upon TA completion.
